poem:
"Epitaph for Edward Howes, Last of the Grand"

From '28 to '71, life's panorama paced,
An English butler donned, stature and vision graced.
In Eaton Square, echoes of a departed scene,
Shoes polished by bone, and servants oh so keen.
Domino falls - the grandeur and the might,
Now silhouettes of butlers vanish in the night.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "The last of England’s grand butlers, 1971 In 1971, the Observer bade farewell not just to Edward Howes – the second-last ‘genuinely grand’ butler in England – but to a whole way of life. Howes entered service in 1928 aged 15 as a ‘hall boy’ in Eaton Square. It was another time in many ways: manservants had to be at least 6ft tall and were forbidden to wear glasses, shoes were polished with a bone,". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
